document: This document covers the fundamentals of algorithm analysis, including asymptotic performance, running time models, worst/average/best case behavior, and practical examples such as bubble sort, insertion sort, selection sort, and linear search.

questions.question: What does the term
refer to?
options: The exact number of operations for a specific input size
How an algorithm behaves as the problem size grows large
The memory usage of an algorithm at runtime
The constant factors hidden in Big-O notation
questions.answer: How an algorithm behaves as the problem size grows large

questions.question: Which assumption is made by the RAM model of computation?
options: Only memory accesses take unit time
All instructions require a variable number of cycles
Function calls are counted in constant time
Memory addresses are not uniformly accessible
questions.answer: Only memory accesses take unit time

questions.question: In the bubble‑sort code snippet, what condition triggers a swap between A[j] and A[j+1]?
What is the worst‑case time complexity of bubble sort?
Which sorting algorithm is known to have an average case time complexity of Θ(n log n)?
In insertion sort, how many comparisons are performed in the worst case?
What is the best‑case time for a linear search if the sought item is at the first position?
What is the purpose of calling srand(time(NULL)) in the sorting program?
options: To seed the random number generator for array initialization
To measure the elapsed clock time
questions.answer: To seed the random number generator for array initialization

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT counted as a primitive step when analyzing algorithm running time?
in algorithm analysis refers to what?
options: The best input arrangement for a given problem size
The expected running time over all equally likely inputs
A fixed number of iterations regardless of input
questions.answer: The expected running time over all equally likely inputs

questions.question: How many passes does bubble sort perform on an array of length n?
In selection sort, what operation is used to find the minimum element of the unsorted portion?
options: Scanning for the smallest value and updating an index
questions.answer: Scanning for the smallest value and updating an index

questions.question: What is the best‑case complexity of insertion sort when the input is already sorted?
In the sorting program, what does clock() measure?
options: CPU time elapsed between two points in code
questions.answer: CPU time elapsed between two points in code

questions.question: What is the worst‑case number of swaps performed by bubble sort?
Which of the following statements about Big‑O notation is correct?
options: It gives an upper bound asymptotically
It always equals the exact running time
questions.answer: It gives an upper bound asymptotically

questions.question: Why is a dynamic array allocated with new int[n] in the sorting program?
options: To allocate memory for a fixed size known at compile time
Because the desired array length is only known at runtime
To store the largest possible integer values
questions.answer: Because the desired array length is only known at runtime

questions.question: In linear search, what does the function return when the searched item is not found?
Which algorithm repeatedly swaps adjacent elements to sort a list?
What is the main output of the sorting program after it has finished sorting?
options: The original unsorted array printed again
A list of random integers from 1 to n
An ascending ordered array of numbers
All elements are printed in reverse order
questions.answer: An ascending ordered array of numbers
